metadata.title: Phase segregation and self-nano-crystallization induced high performance Li-storage in metal-organic framework bulks for advanced lithium ion batteries

Nano Energy

Full paper
Phase segregation and self-nano-crystallization induced high performance Li-storage in metal-organic framework bulks for advanced lithium ion batteries
Huawei Song, Lisha Shen, Jing Wang, Chengxin Wang⁎
State Key Laboratory of Optoelectronic Materials and Technologies, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Sun Yat-Sen (Zhongshan) University, Guangzhou 510275, People's Republic of China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: MOF Inorganic-organic hybrid composites Phase segregation Self-nano-crystallization Li-ion storage Full cells
A B S T R A C T
Recently, metal organic framework (MOF) materials in nano-scale have gained enormous interest in Li-ion batteries (LIBs), while those in bulks usually exhibit poor Li-ion storage performance. Herein, we report how to obtain impressive Li-ion storage performance by using MOF bulks firstly. Through suitable design, incorporating small inorganic nano-domains with various dimensions into the MOF bulks, the forming metal inorganicorganic hybrid composites (M-IOHCs) could store Li-ions twice more than that of the metal based MOF (MMOF) bulks. Except for the good Li-ion storage performance, exemplified M-IOHCs also exhibit enhancing cyclibility of more than 400 cycles with tripled capacity and 100% capacity retention. The enhanced Li-ion storage capability and cyclibility is attributed not only to local phase segregation in MOF bulks induced by ultra small inorganic nano-domains and the self-nano-crystallization of MOF bulks and the later forming inorganic nanocrystals themselves, but also to the stabilized frameworks comprised of metal oxide inorganic nanocrystals and enwrapped C-N organic species which brought up no aggregation or grow-up of the inorganic active materials common in new generation electrode materials. Application of the M-IOHCs in full cells was exemplified by Ni-IOHCs anode and commercial LiFePO4 cathode, which delivers excellent energy and power performance.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Searching suitable electrode materials has always been one of the hottest topics in LIBs’ development, although the Li-ion storage mechanisms range from traditional graphite-like intercalation to the next generation conversion and alloy reaction [1]. Generally, the candidates for most promising electrodes should not only afford large Li-ion storage capacity, but also could suffer battery operations durably enough. In this sense, various nanostructures and/or composites among transition metal oxides and their composites have been focused and achieved fast advances in promoting the development of LIBs [2– 9]. Adhered to the cultivation-new-materials-oriented thoughts, the electrode materials have been extended from inorganic to organic in recently years, although the application is still faced with many challenges, such as poor conductivity and thermal stability, easy mass loss due to considerable solubility in current electrolyte systems, and severe low utilization efficiency [10–14]. However, important contributions are stilled made in the following regards, such as nano-sized Prussian for lithium ion, sodium ion, potassium ion, magnesium ion,
and calcium ion storage based on intercalation-like mechanism, alkali metal salts of benzoic derivatives and conjugated carbonyl derivatives for Li-ion and Na-ion storage by redox of conjugated C=O [15–26].
MOFs, as one of the main inorganic organic hybrid materials, are roughly divided as porous MOFs and dense MOFs. Benefitting from the abundant interpenetrating pores and tunnels, MOFs are theoretically attractive for addressing the bottleneck issues faced by new generation electrode materials, such as huge volume effect, pulverization, and sluggish ion transport kinetics [27,28]. Due to non-three-dimension (non-3D) inorganic connectivity, the porous MOFs have recently gained enormous interest in energy storage benefiting by fast transport kinetics for small molecules and/or ions and large structural adaptability owing to large organic breathing effect, while dense MOF materials are mainly focused in many physical fields as superconductivity, multiferroic, nonlinear optical effect, photovoltaic and optoelectronic related devices [29–34]. As to Li-ion storage, MOFs have achieved considerable development as shown in Table 1. The capacity for the cathodes has been increased from 140 to 250 mAh g−1 with the lifespan being expanded five times, while the Li-ion storage capability

Through introducing inorganic nano-domains into MOF bulks, we have improved not only the Li-ion storage capability and cyclibility (1043 mAhg-1 at 0.2 Ag-1 for 450 cycles) for MOFs, but also raised the initial coulombic efficiency up to more than 83%. The capacity increase happening in MOFs is just like that of inorganic active materials due to transition of the Li-storage mechanism from intercalation type to conjugated functional groups and inorganic ion active sites related redox reaction. Therefore, one of the main measures adopted in pursuit of Li-ion storage performance improvements for MOFs is choosing ligands with more conjugated active sites and MOFs with lighter molecular weight. This corresponds that more Li ions could be utilized with MOFs in the same weight. Another measure is to fabricate MOF nanostructures which are more favorable for attaining high lithium storage capability and fast charge-discharge processes due to short lithiation depth and abundant interfaces. So far, nanoparticles, nanocubes, nanowires, and nanosheets have been investigated for nonaqueous alkali metal ion storage [22,25,38–41]. It's to note that MOF bulks in micrometer scale most exhibit poor Li-ion storage performance or cyclibility. Interestingly, a bimetallic coordination polymer (BCP) derived from Co-Zn-MOF delivered excellent Li-storage capability and cyclibility, but the hollow porous amorphous-like BCP by water etching is somewhat as MOF derivatives obtained through controlled thermal treatment, and hence it technically should be included in the inorganic composites to some extent [37]. Moreover, the insight reasons for the abnormal electrochemical performance need to be further discussed.
Through controlled evaporation of some organic ligands, we discovered the electrochemical performance of the MOF bulks could be significant improved as shown in Scheme 1. The Mn-MOF bulks deliver a poor reversible capacity only 310 mAh g−1 with very low coulombic efficiency of 34.3%, while the derived Mn inorganic-organic hybrid composites (Mn-IOHCs) show marked electrochemical improvement with doubled capacity (661 mAh g−1) and highly elevated initial efficiency of 53.7%. Could the improvements be extended to other MOF bulks and what caused the Li-storage capability increase? Herein, we introduced inorganic nano-domains and/or nanocrystals (0–20 nm) into MOF bulks to promote their application in LIBs for the first time, fabricating a series of metal inorganic-organic hybrid
composites (M-IOHCs (Given no special instructions, M refers to Mn, Co, Ni in the whole text)), investigating its application in LIBs, and visually screening the microstructure and morphology evolutions which substantiated local phase segregation and self-nano-crystallization are crucial to the significant electrochemical performance enhancements.

sections.heading: 2.1. M-MOF and M-IOHCs Synthesis
sections.text: The M-MOFs were synthesized by a modified solvothermal method followed by crystallization [32,42]. MCl2 (M=Mn, Ni, Co) solution about 0.14 M in H2O/N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, V/V=1) was hydrothermally treated at 140 °C for 48 h. The filling rate of the autoclave is about 60%. After slowly cooling to room temperature, the supernatant transparent solution was held for about five days to obtain colorless Mn-MOF, purple Co-MOF and green Ni-MOF bulks by slowly vaporization at room temperature (the evaporation temperature should be held about 38 °C). The residual Cl- and solvent could be washed by ethanol for twice or three times. In preparing M-IOHCs, the slowly vaporization at room temperature is substituted by controlled vaporization at 90 °C for 12 h. The other procedures are carried out the same as those for M-MOFs.

sections.heading: 2.2. Materials characterization
sections.text:
Morphologies of the samples were characterized by a thermal field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) (Quanta 400 F) under 20 kV and a transmission electron microscope (TEM) (FEI Tecnai G2 F30) under 300 kV. Structures, composition and elemental analysis were performed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) (D/MAX 2200 VPC), energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR, Bruker EQUINOX 55), and X-ray photoelectron energy spectroscopy (XPS). The XRD was scanned at 5°/min from 10° to 55° (2θ) with Cu kα1 as X-ray radiation source. Elemental analysis (EA) and inductively coupled plasma-atomic absorption spectroscopy (ICP) were used to confirm the content of N and M (Mn, Co, Ni) in the M-MOFs and M-IOHCs respectively. The surface area and pore
analysis were carried out on a Micromeritics instrument (ASAP 2420) with N2 as absorbate at 77 K. The specific surface area and pore distribution were evaluated based on Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface and nonlocal density functional theory respectively.

sections.heading: 2.3. Cell assembly and characterization
sections.text:
For electrochemical characterization in half lithium ion batteries, a slurry mixture containing M-MOF or M-IOHCs, acetylene black and polyvinylidene fluoride with a weight ratio of 7:2:1 was firstly made through adding a small amount of 1-Methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP). The electrodes were fabricated by pasting the slurry mixture on copper foil by an automatic thick film coater (AFA-I). Then the coating film was desiccated in an vacuum chamber at 90 °C for 12 h. After that the foil is pressed by an electromotive roller (MR-100A) and tailored to appropriate size by a coin-type cell microtome (T-06). The loadage of active materials (~1.5 mg) on each piece was determined by a microbalance (d=0.1 μg). Standard cells (CR2032) with the above tailored foils as working electrode and lithium foils as the reference and counter electrode, polypropylene micromembrane (Celgard 2500) as the separator, 1 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate (EC) and diethyl carbonate (DEC) with a weight ratio of 1:1 as the electrolyte, were assembled in an Ar-filled universal glove box with the Oxygen and water vapor pressure less than 0.3 ppm. For cycling and rate performance, the cells were galvanostatically charged and discharged in a volatage cutoff of 0.005–3 V at various rates on a mulitichannel Neware battery testing system. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) scanning from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz with an ac signal amplitude of 10 mV was carried out on an Ivium electrochemical workstation.
To analyze the Li-storage mechanism, newly fabricated cells were galvanostatically discharged and/or charged to different cutoff voltages at 50 mA g−1. The cycled cells were disassembled in an Ar-filled glove box and held for 5 days for naturally drying. The dry electrodes were directly used to carry out the ex-situ XRD characterization. The scraped powders were collected for ex-situ FT-IR, XPS, and TEM characterization.
To exemplify the application of M-IOHCs in full lithium ion batteries, coin-type cells with commercial LiFePO4 (Hefei kejing,
China) as the cathode (~9.5 mg cm−2) and Ni-IOHCs as the anode (~1.5 mg cm−2) were fabricated according to our previous reported MOF nanowires cells [38]. For cycling, the full batteries were galvanostatically charged and discharged in a volatage cutoff of 0.4–3.8 V at various rates on a mulitichannel Neware battery testing system.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
Dense M-MOFs bulks, exemplified by perovskite Me2NH2M(HCOO)3 (Me=CH3, M=Mn, Co, Ni) with a trigonal symmetry (Space group: R-3c, α=β=90°, γ=120°, aMn=8.331(2) Å, cMn=22.888(4) Å, aCo=8.317(1) Å, cCo=22.805(6) Å, aNi=8.138(3) Å, cNi=21.952(8) Å), were synthesized by hydrothermally treating 0.14 MMCl2 (M=Mn, Co, Ni) solution of H2O/N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, V/V=1) at 140 °C for 48 h and subsequently holding the transparent solution for five days [32,42]. Taking MnMOF as an example, Fig. 1 displays the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern for the as-synthesized sample consistent with that of the simulated one, indicating the good phase-purity of the Mn-MOFs. The 3D atomic structural graphs show the Mn-MOF is comprised of 3D framework of Mn-O octahedron connected by HCOO-, and C-N hexahedra connected by Me2NH2 are inserted into the interval of Mn-O frameworks.
In order to construct M-IOHCs, the hydrothermal treated transparent solutions for the M-MOFs were treated with a mild vaporization process at 90 °C for 12 h. The XRD patterns exhibit the as-synthesized products are comprised of two phases (Fig. 2a). One is the M-MOF, and the other is M(HCOO)2 (M=Mn, Co, Ni) hydrate with a monoclinic symmetry (Space group: P21/c, α=β=90°. For Mn, γ=97.88°, a=8.881 Å, b=7.267 Å, c=9.643 Å; for Co, γ=104°, a=8.580 Å, b=7.120 Å, c=9.2000 Å; for Ni, γ=104°, a=8.580 Å, b=7.120 Å, c=9.2000 Å). In order to confirm the content of M-MOFs in the MIOHCs, ICP, EA, and TGA tests were performed (Fig. 2c-d and Table S1). The content of M-MOFs in M-IOHCs for Mn, Co, and Ni is about 81.13%, 24.17%, and 44.03% respectively. The SEM images display the M-IOHCs appear as irregular large bulks from submicron scale to several micrometers (Fig. S1). Inset views of energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectra indicate only C, N, O, and M exist in the composites (Fig. S1). The porous surface of Mn IOHCs in the TEM images (Fig. S1 and Fig. 3) imply the Mn-MOF suffered from a slight evacuation of some C-

N species, and the well-defined diffraction rings in the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) image indicates the circled area are polycrystalline, while no distinct lattice fringes for the crystals may be resulted from that those Mn inorganic species are almost all in the
form of ultra small nano-domains consistent with very low content of Mn(HCOO)2 hydrate (19.87%). The crystal size of the incorporating inorganic species increases to ca. 5 nm for Ni IOHCs and 20 nm for Co IOHCs (Fig. 3). This indicates dimensions of the embedded inorganic
nanocrystals are highly dependent on their contents. Through adjusting the content, a suitable hybrid composite framework could be achieved just like that of Ni-IOHCs.
Li-storage performance of the M-IOHCs is presented in Fig. 4. When tested at 50 mA g−1 (Voltage range: 0.005–3 V), the M-IOHCs electrodes (Fig. 4a) exhibit excellent Li-storage capability with the initial capacity of 1655 mAh g−1 for Co and Ni, and 1873 mAh g−1 for Mn. The reversible capacity of 802 mAh g−1 for Mn, 959 mAh g−1 for Co, and 1212 mAh g−1 for Ni is retained, corresponding to an initial coulombic efficiency of 42.8%, 57.9%, and 73.2% respectively. Apparently, the performance highly relies on their microstructures, and neither more nor less of embedded inorganic
crystals are essential to obtain high reversible ion storage capability and initial coulombic efficiency. The microstructure-relevant phenomenon also happened for the rate performance and cyclibility (Fig. 4b-d). The best rate performance is achieved in Ni-IOHCs electrode, specifically, 1250 mAh g−1 at 50 mA g−1, 1215 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1, 1018 mAh g−1 at 200 mAh g−1, 808 mAh g−1 at 500 mA g−1, 604 mAh g−1 at 1 A g−1, 350 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1, and 152 mAh g−1 at 5 A g−1 respectively. When the rate was returned to 50 mA g−1, the capability could fully recover as the initial stage in several cycles. Importantly, all the M-IOHCs e exhibit excellent cyclibility for more than 400 cycles of 1050 mAh g−1 for Ni and 893 mAh g−1 for Co at 200 mA g−1, and 607 mAh g−1 for Mn at 500 mA g−1 respectively, much
higher than the MOF bulks of only 300 mAh g−1 at 200 mA g−1. The coulombic efficiency all rises up to nearly 100% after initial several cycles. Interestingly, a pre-process of increasing Li-ion storage capability lasted on for about 50 cycles for Mn and Co, without any increasing for Ni and pure M-MOF bulks. This might be resulted from too little inorganic species in Mn and too much in Co, through which the enhancement of the electrochemical performance was induced. The invariable cyclibility of the pure MOF bulks substantiates the inducement is essential in obtaining related enhancement for electrochemical performance.
To fully understand the reason for inorganic species in modifying the electrochemical performance of the MOF bulks, the lithiation mechanism of M-IOHCs was exemplified by Mn-IOHCs. Fig. 5a-d presents the phase and chemical state evolutions of the Mn-IOHCs electrodes held at different charge-discharge stages. The evolution of
ex-situ Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) depicts the FT-IR spectrum of pristine Mn-IOHCs is characterized of three series of featured bands around 569 cm−1 for Mn(II)-O stretching vibration (υMn(II)-O) in Mn-O octahedron frameworks, 898, 1087, 1360, 1587, 3300 cm−1 for HCOO- and O-H related vibrations (898 cm−1 for stretching vibrations of H-O in HCOO- due to inner molecular H-bond (υsO-H), 1087 cm
−1 for symmetric stretching vibrations of C-O (υssC-O), 1360 and 1587 cm−1 for asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carbonyls (υassC=O, υ ss C=O), and broad band near 3300 cm
−1 for stretching vibrations of hydroxyl duo to intermolecular H-bond (υsOH)), and 796, 1022, 1463, 2507, 2832, 3037, 3150 cm
−1 due to Me2NH2
+ relevant vibrations (796 and 3037 cm−1 for C-H deforming and stretching vibrations (υdC-H, υ s C-H) in Me, 1022, 2507, 2832 cm −1 for symmetric and asymmetric deforming and stretching vibrations of
C-N (υsdC-N, υ asd C-N, and υ s C-N) in Me2NH2 +, 1463 and 3150 cm−1 for N-H deforming and stretching vibrations (υdC-H, υ s C-H)) [43]. The fact that Mn(II)-O vibration absorbance peaks have been always existing indicates Mn(II)-O frameworks in the MOFs continuously become
inorganic and Mn(II) hasn't reduced to Mn(0) as in inorganic MnOx electrodes in the first discharge-charge process [44]. Their broadening and sharpening further implies that Mn(II) in Mn-O frameworks have participated in the incomplete redox reaction. The weakening of C-N
absorbance peaks (1022, 2507 and 2832 cm−1 in A→B→C) in discharging and emerging dicarbonyl (O=C-C=O) absorbance peaks (1805 cm−1 in C→D→E) in charging processes verify that both carbonyls and aminomethyls contributed to the Li-ion storage capability of the MOFs. The emerging C-O-C stretching (1181 cm−1), ring deforming (783 cm−1), C˭N stretching (1523 cm−1) absorbance bands, and the splitting off N-H vibrations bands (834, 864, and 1433 cm−1) in the discharging indirectly proves the existence of chaining reaction and ring-formation caused by organic redox reaction [38].
Ex-situ XRD patterns evolution indicates the lithiation-delithiation of Mn-IOHCs is accompanied with reversible conversion of Mn-MOF and its self-nano-crystallization. The broadening diffraction peaks around 14.5° and 22.5° (2θ) reveal Mn-MOF in the Mn-IOHCs suffered severely self-nano-crystallization after fully discharging to 0.005 V. The re-emerging Mn-MOF diffraction peaks in-situ superimposed with broadening peaks indicate that the organic frameworks could be reversibly recovered, but only partially due to newly forming Mn based inorganic nanocrystals in the fully charged stage. The deconvoluted C1s, N1s, and Mn2p X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra in pristine Mn-IOHCs show C-O (266.2 eV) and C=O (288.6 eV) bonding due to HCOO-, R2–NH2 + bonding (399.8 and 402.1 eV) for Me2NH2 +, and Mn(II) for Mn-O frameworks [45]. In the fully discharging stage, the emerging peak around 289.9 eV for C1s ascribed to satellite of π-π* for conjugated C and the vanishing peak at 402.1 eV was well consistent with conjugated C=N derived from ring and chain reaction that analyzed by FT-IR spectra, and the splitting of Mn 2p3/2 into two peaks around 641.2 and 624.8 eV indicate Mn based disproportionation-like reaction happened, meaning Mn(II) in Mn-O organic framework is partially reduced without any Mn(0). It is speculated that the Mn (641.2 eV) is probably inorganic Mn-O species as MnO around 641.4 eV, while the Mn (624.8 eV) is mostly organic Mn-O species as the pristine sample, unless the intensifying peak for Mn (641.2) in the fully charging stage could not be rationalized. Moreover, it is well supported by the intensifying satellite peak around 645.0 eV for inorganic MnO in the fully charging stage. Considering XRD and FTIR results, this speculation is also reasonable. As a result of ring and chain reaction, the organic Mn becomes partially inorganic leading to phase segregation and self-nano-crystallization in the Mn-MOFs, and further the binding energy of rest organic Mn also shifts higher for changing in surrounding chemical atmosphere, while in the charging organic Mn is reversibly converted into Mn-MOF due to unfolding reaction of organic chain and ring accompanied with the forming of conjugated dicarbonyl, further phase segregation of Mn-MOFs, and the increase of inorganic Mn-O species well accordance to the higher shifting of C=O (C1s, 289.0 eV) and increasing intensity of Mn peak around 641.2 eV.
Through tracking TEM images during batteries operation (Fig. 6ad), we further analyzed how did the phase segregation and self-nano-
crystallization effect in adjusting the microstructures of the Mn-MOF bulks to obtain Li-ion storage performance enhancement. After one cycle, distinct phase segregation and nano-crystallization have happened bringing up inorganic nanocrystals about a dozen nanometers with well-defined lattice fringes and diffraction rings. Meanwhile, MOF-bulks in micrometer scale also break into irregular fragments about 50–200 nm. When lasting for 10 cycles, only sporadic large fragments less than 50 nm still exist, and most of the Mn species become inorganic nanocrystals about 5 nm. The marked nano-crystallization last for about 50 cycles, thereby forming a stabilized inorganicorganic framework with the inorganic Mn-O crystals about 3 nm and C-N organic species uniformly enwrapped. Scheme 2 briefly illustrates the evolution of the Mn-IOHCs and well explains why the electrochemical performance of the Mn-MOF bulks could be modified by fabricating Mn-IOHCs. It's also the reasons for the increasing cycling performance for Mn IOHCs for about 50 cycles, and then stable cyclibility was achieved, well consistent to no increasing Li-ion cyclibility for the Ni IOHCs with coordinating inorganic nanocrystals uniformly embedded in Ni-MOFs at an elegant manner.
Combining the XRD, XPS, IR, and TEM analysis, we could conclude that M-IOHCs firstly evolved into a stable framework comprising of inorganic MOx nanocrystals and organic C-N cages enwrapping outside in initial cycles, and then MOx/C-N hybrids perform as other organicinorganic frameworks with both the MOx and C-N cages contributing to the Li-ion storage as reported [38]. This could be verified by the variation in the differential capacity curves tested after different cycles (inset views of Scheme 1 and Fig. S7). In the initial cycles, only one redox couple exists around 0.6 V vs. 1.1 V ascribing to redox of inorganic MOx nano-domains. Redox couple for organic species has not appeared due to very little amount of organic species available only in the surface, explaining why their transformation were detected by XPS and IR results. After the initial process, emerging redox peaks about 1.1 V vs. 2.1 V (Fig. S7) could be probably attributed to the redox reaction of C-N species [38]. The steady redox reactions after the initial process are well consistent with the stable cycling stability shown in Fig. 4. In general, the electrochemical process of M-IOHCs could be described as M-IOHCs→MOx/C-N hybrid (I) and MOx/C-N hybrid (high energy state)↔M/C-N hybrid(low energy state) (II). Formula I could be used to describe the initial stabilizing process and formula II depicts the lithiation and delithiation of stabilized framework of MOx/ C-N hybrid.
Therefore, we chose Ni IOHCs (almost no need of initial stabilizing process) as an example to explain the application of M IOHCs in full cells with Ni IOHCs as the anode (~1.5 mg cm−2), and commercial LiFePO4 powders as the cathode (~9.5 mg cm
−2), to note that all the capacities and energy and power densities are calculated based on the total weight of both the anode and the cathode. Fig. 7 shows the full cell exhibits stable cycling performance with a reversible capacity of
Scheme 2. illustrations depict why the electrochemical performance of the Mn-MOF bulks could be modified by fabricating Mn-IOHCs.
140 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C (Voltage: 0.4–3.8 V) (here, n C corresponds to a 1/n hour discharging process). When being tested at varying rates from 0.1C to 4.3 C, the cell also delivers good storage capability and cyclibility of 143 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C, 120 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C, 88 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C, and 75 mAh g−1 at 1 C and recoverable capability for more than 80 cycles with an average discharging voltage ca. 2 V. Besides, high energy density of 297 Wh kg−1 at 32 W kg−1 and 90 Wh kg−1 at 384 W kg were also achieved, superior to most currently reported advanced devices and MOF nanowires counterparts based on the total weight of both electrodes [38,46].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, we have modified the synthetic methods for synthesis organic-inorganic perovskites MOFs, incorporating inorganic nanodomains and/or nanocrystals into organic MOF bulks. We discovered the Li-storage capability and cyclibility for the MOFs bulks could be significantly improved through designing inorganic nanocrystals embedded MOF hybrid composites for the first time. Inorganic species of nano-domains and/or nanocrystals are crucial to induce phase segregation and self-nano-crystallization of MOF bulks bringing up a stabilized M-IOHCs with elegantly embedded inorganic nanocrystals and organic species frameworks enwrapping outside which account for the enhanced ion storage capability and cyclibility. The inorganic species induced phase segregation and self-nano-crystallization of MOF bulks in modifying electrochemical properties opens up a newly avenues to promote the application of MOFs in energy storage fields in future.

metadata.abstractText: Recently, metal organic framework (MOF) materials in nano-scale have gained enormous interest in Li-ion batteries (LIBs), while those in bulks usually exhibit poor Li-ion storage performance. Herein, we report how to obtain impressive Li-ion storage performance by using MOF bulks firstly. Through suitable design, incorporating small inorganic nano-domains with various dimensions into the MOF bulks, the forming metal inorganicorganic hybrid composites (M-IOHCs) could store Li-ions twice more than that of the metal based MOF (MMOF) bulks. Except for the good Li-ion storage performance, exemplified M-IOHCs also exhibit enhancing cyclibility of more than 400 cycles with tripled capacity and 100% capacity retention. The enhanced Li-ion storage capability and cyclibility is attributed not only to local phase segregation in MOF bulks induced by ultra small inorganic nano-domains and the self-nano-crystallization of MOF bulks and the later forming inorganic nanocrystals themselves, but also to the stabilized frameworks comprised of metal oxide inorganic nanocrystals and enwrapped C-N organic species which brought up no aggregation or grow-up of the inorganic active materials common in new generation electrode materials. Application of the M-IOHCs in full cells was exemplified by Ni-IOHCs anode and commercial LiFePO4 cathode, which delivers excellent energy and power performance.
